Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Towards Agile and Privacy-Preserving Cloud Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cloud computing offers many benefits to users, including increased availability and flexibility of resources, and efficiency of equipment. However, privacy concerns are becoming a major barrier to users transitioning to cloud computing. The privilege design of existing cloud platforms creates great challenges in ensuring the trustworthiness of cloud by granting too much power to the cloud administrators, who could launch serious insider attacks by abusing the administrative privileges.

This project uses a well-understood philosophy, separation-of-privilege, in the architectural design of a cloud platform. The architectural design and the strong homomorphic cryptographic approach protect data privacy in cloud environments from different angles. This project develops an innovative privacy-driven architectural design, with one focus on the privilege-level design of each software component of a cloud platform, and another on defending insider attacks. This project investigates new mechanisms to de-privilege the cloud administrator and enable more fine grained access control among the software components of a cloud platform. More specifically, the new mechanisms enable agile configuration of the platform; user-configurable privacy protection; and strong isolation in the user space. The techniques developed under this project are immensely important as users place more of their data into the cloud and rely upon cloud providers to keep that data private.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cloud computing is becoming the infrastructure of our daily computing, storage, mobile computing, IoT services, etc. On one side, privacy protection is important when we move services into the cloud environments. On the other side, it is important to make sure that security mechanism and measures can be cross-platform, so they can be applied in different cloud environment. 

First, we investigated how privacy protection can be compromised through possible side channels on both x86 and ARM architectures. Through experimental studies, we compared bandwidths of side channels on different architectures between two virtual machines. Also, we investigated how the bandwidth can be affected by system noise. Furthermore, through noise injection, we investigated how the bandwidth of side channels can be reduced to the level of not being practical. The results provide guidelines how to measure the risks of side-channel attacks in the cloud environments on different processor architectures. 

Second, we investigated how virtual machine placement can affect the security risks of a cloud. At the beginning, we used manually selected metrics and rules to guide the virtual machine placement in the cloud. Our developed algorithm and rules can significantly reduce the security risks of a cloud through virtual machine placement. Later on, using datasets from real world clouds, we deployed machine learning algorithms to estimate the security risks automatically. Since the training was using real world datasets, our approach works better than the estimate using handpicked metrics and rules. The estimate of security risks is more accurate.  

Through the project, two Ph.D. students received support. The research results have been published in journals and conferences.
